hints: This scientific principle changed how we understand motion
Named after an English physicist and mathematician
Also known as the Law of Inertia
States that objects at rest stay at rest unless acted upon by force
F = ma is related, but this is specifically about objects in motion or at rest
This Renaissance master created some of the world's most famous paintings
Born in Italy in the 15th century
Known for both art and scientific inventions
Painted the Mona Lisa
Also painted The Last Supper
This process is essential for life on Earth
Involves converting light energy into chemical energy
Plants use this to create food from sunlight
Produces oxygen as a byproduct
Uses chlorophyll and occurs mainly in leaves
This is the highest point on Earth
Located in the Himalayas
Sits on the border between Nepal and Tibet
Many climbers attempt to reach its summit each year
Also known as Sagarmatha in Nepali
This global conflict lasted from 1939 to 1945
Involved most of the world's nations
Featured the Holocaust and atomic bomb usage
Axis powers fought against Allied powers
Ended with Germany and Japan's surrender
This scientist is often called the Father of Relativity
He developed the famous equation E=mc²
He won the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921
His wild hair and mustache made him instantly recognizable
He was born in Germany but later became an American citizen
This ancient structure stretches for thousands of miles
It was built to protect against invasions from the north
Construction began in the 7th century BC
It is visible from space (though this is a myth)
It winds through deserts, grasslands, and mountains in Asia
This English playwright is considered the greatest writer in the English language
He wrote 39 plays and 154 sonnets
His works include tragedies, comedies, and histories
He created characters like Hamlet, Romeo, and Juliet
He lived from 1564 to 1616 in Stratford-upon-Avon
This "unsinkable" ship sank on its maiden voyage in 1912
It hit an iceberg in the North Atlantic Ocean
Over 1,500 people died in the disaster
It was traveling from Southampton to New York City
James Cameron made a famous movie about this tragedy
This is the largest planet in our solar system
It is a gas giant with no solid surface
It has a Great Red Spot that is actually a giant storm
It has over 80 known moons
Its four largest moons were discovered by Galileo
This molecule carries genetic information in all living things
It has a double helix structure
Watson, Crick, and Franklin were key in discovering its structure
It stands for deoxyribonucleic acid
It is made up of four bases: A, T, G, and C
This famous painting hangs in the Louvre Museum in Paris
It was painted by Leonardo da Vinci
The subject has a mysterious smile
It was stolen in 1911 but recovered two years later
The subject is believed to be Lisa Gherardini
This element makes up about 21% of Earth's atmosphere
All animals need this to breathe and survive
Its chemical symbol is O
It has an atomic number of 8
Plants produce this during photosynthesis
This British band formed in Liverpool in 1960
They were known as the Fab Four
Their members included John, Paul, George, and Ringo
They had hits like "Hey Jude" and "Let It Be"
They appeared on The Ed Sullivan Show in 1964
This is the longest river in South America
It flows through the world's largest rainforest
It empties into the Atlantic Ocean
It has over 1,100 tributaries
It flows through Brazil, Peru, Colombia, and other countries
This organelle is often called the powerhouse of the cell
It produces ATP, the cell's energy currency
It has its own DNA separate from the cell nucleus
It is believed to have evolved from ancient bacteria
Muscle cells contain many of these due to high energy needs
This Dutch post-impressionist painter cut off his own ear
He only sold one painting during his lifetime
His works include "Starry Night" and "Sunflowers"
He suffered from mental illness and died at age 37
His brother Theo supported him financially throughout his life
This antibiotic was discovered accidentally in 1928
It was found growing as mold in a petri dish
Alexander Fleming discovered it
It saved millions of lives during World War II
It comes from a type of fungus called Penicillium
This is the largest hot desert in the world
It covers much of North Africa
It is roughly the size of the United States
Its name means "desert" in Arabic
It experiences extreme temperature differences between day and night
This naturalist developed the theory of evolution
He sailed on the HMS Beagle to the Galápagos Islands
He wrote "On the Origin of Species"
His theory explains how species change over time
He proposed the concept of natural selection
This structure divided a major European city from 1961 to 1989
It separated East and West during the Cold War
Ronald Reagan famously said "Tear down this wall!"
Its fall marked the beginning of German reunification
It was built overnight to prevent people from escaping to the West
This was the last active pharaoh of ancient Egypt
She had relationships with Julius Caesar and Mark Antony
She spoke nine languages and was highly educated
She died by snake bite (according to legend)
Elizabeth Taylor famously portrayed her in a 1963 film
This is the largest ocean on Earth
It covers about one-third of the planet's surface
It contains the Mariana Trench, the deepest point on Earth
It separates Asia and Australia from the Americas
Its name means "peaceful" in Latin
This composer was a child prodigy who started composing at age 5
He lived from 1756 to 1791
He composed over 600 works in his short life
His full name was Wolfgang Amadeus
He wrote famous operas like "The Magic Flute" and "Don Giovanni"
This cosmic object has gravity so strong that nothing can escape it
Not even light can escape from beyond its event horizon
Einstein's theory of relativity predicted their existence
The first image of one was captured in 2019
They form when massive stars collapse at the end of their lives
This novel was written by F. Scott Fitzgerald
It's set in the Jazz Age of the 1920s
The story is narrated by Nick Carraway
It features the mysterious millionaire Jay Gatsby
The green light at the end of Daisy's dock is a famous symbol
This ancient city is located high in the Andes Mountains
It was built by the Inca civilization in the 15th century
It's often called the "Lost City of the Incas"
It was rediscovered by Hiram Bingham in 1911
It's located in modern-day Peru
This muscular organ pumps blood throughout the body
It has four chambers: two atria and two ventricles
It beats about 100,000 times per day
It's roughly the size of a clenched fist
It's located slightly left of center in the chest
This cultural movement began in Italy in the 14th century
It marked the transition from medieval to modern times
It was characterized by renewed interest in art, science, and learning
Famous figures include Leonardo da Vinci and Michelangelo
The name means "rebirth" in French
This monument was a gift from France to the United States
It stands on an island in New York Harbor
It was designed by Frédéric Auguste Bartholdi
It holds a torch in one hand and a tablet in the other
It was dedicated in 1886 and symbolizes freedom and democracy
This fundamental force attracts objects with mass toward each other
Sir Isaac Newton described it after observing a falling apple
Einstein later described it as the curvature of spacetime
It keeps planets in orbit around the sun
It's the weakest of the four fundamental forces
These ancient structures are among the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World
They were built as tombs for Egyptian pharaohs
The largest was built for Pharaoh Khufu
They are located near Cairo, Egypt
The Great Sphinx guards these monuments
This composer continued to write music even after losing his hearing
He composed nine symphonies
His most famous piece might be "Ode to Joy"
He lived from 1770 to 1827
His first name was Ludwig van
This body system controls and coordinates all body functions
It consists of the brain, spinal cord, and nerves
It processes information and sends signals throughout the body
Neurons are the basic cells of this system
It can be divided into central and peripheral parts
This is Shakespeare's longest play
The protagonist is the Prince of Denmark
Features the famous soliloquy "To be or not to be"
The main character seeks revenge for his father's murder
Contains the play-within-a-play scene
This global network connects billions of devices worldwide
It originated from ARPANET in the 1960s
Tim Berners-Lee invented the World Wide Web on this
It uses protocols like HTTP, TCP/IP, and DNS
Social media, email, and websites all use this infrastructure
This scientist was the first woman to win a Nobel Prize
She discovered the elements polonium and radium
She was born in Poland but worked in France
She won Nobel Prizes in both Physics and Chemistry
She died from radiation exposure due to her research
This celestial body causes tides on Earth
It's about 238,900 miles from Earth
Apollo 11 was the first mission to land here
It has phases: new, waxing, full, and waning
Neil Armstrong was the first human to walk on it
This conflict lasted from 1861 to 1865
It was fought between the Union and the Confederacy
Abraham Lincoln was president during this war
It began with the attack on Fort Sumter
It ended slavery in the United States
This Spanish artist co-founded the Cubist movement
He painted "Guernica" depicting the horrors of war
His Blue Period featured predominantly blue paintings
He lived from 1881 to 1973
His full name was Pablo Diego José Francisco de Paula Juan Nepomuceno
This is the smallest and shallowest ocean
It surrounds the North Pole
It's mostly covered by sea ice year-round
Polar bears live around its edges
Climate change is rapidly affecting this ocean
These medicines fight bacterial infections
Penicillin was the first widely used one
They don't work against viral infections
Overuse can lead to resistance
Alexander Fleming discovered the first one by accident
This revolution began in 1789
It overthrew the monarchy in France
Marie Antoinette was executed during this period
The slogan was "Liberty, Equality, Fraternity"
It led to the rise of Napoleon Bonaparte
This form of energy powers most modern devices
Benjamin Franklin studied it with kites and keys
It flows through conductors like copper wire
Lightning is a natural form of this phenomenon
It can be generated by moving magnets near coils
This is traditionally considered the longest river in the world
It flows through Egypt and several other African countries
Ancient Egyptian civilization developed along its banks
It floods annually, depositing fertile soil
The Aswan High Dam was built to control its flow
These prehistoric reptiles dominated Earth for millions of years
They went extinct about 66 million years ago
Some evolved into modern birds
T. Rex and Triceratops are famous examples
Their fossils help us understand ancient life
This body system defends against diseases and infections
White blood cells are its main soldiers
It can remember previous infections for faster response
Vaccines train this system to recognize threats
It includes organs like the spleen and lymph nodes
This is Shakespeare's most famous tragedy about young love
It features two feuding families in Verona
The Montagues and Capulets are the warring houses
The protagonists die in the end
Friar Lawrence secretly marries the couple
This is the coldest and windiest continent
It's almost entirely covered by ice
No permanent human residents live here
It contains about 70% of the world's fresh water
Research stations from many countries operate here
This chart organizes all known chemical elements
Dmitri Mendeleev created the first version
Elements are arranged by atomic number
It predicts properties of undiscovered elements
Hydrogen is the first element on this table
This Italian pasta dish originated in Rome
Made with eggs, cheese, pancetta, and black pepper
The name means "charcoal burner's pasta"
No cream is used in the authentic recipe
Traditionally made with Pecorino Romano cheese
This Japanese dish features vinegared rice
Often served with raw fish or seafood
Wasabi and pickled ginger are common accompaniments
Chopsticks are traditionally used to eat this
Popular varieties include maki, nigiri, and sashimi
This buttery, flaky pastry originated in France
Has a distinctive crescent shape
Made with laminated dough containing butter layers
Often eaten for breakfast with coffee
Can be filled with chocolate, almonds, or ham and cheese
This rice dish originated in Valencia, Spain
Traditionally cooked in a wide, shallow pan
Contains saffron which gives it a yellow color
Classic version includes rabbit, chicken, and beans
Seafood versions are popular in coastal areas
This Mexican dish consists of a folded tortilla
Can be filled with meat, vegetables, or beans
Often topped with salsa, onions, and cilantro
Corn tortillas are traditional, flour tortillas are also used
Street vendors are famous for serving these
This spiced dish originated in South Asian cuisine
Made with a variety of spices like turmeric and cumin
Can be made with meat, vegetables, or legumes
Often served with rice or bread like naan
Different regions have their own unique versions
This sweet treat comes from cacao beans
The Aztecs and Mayans first cultivated the cacao plant
Can be dark, milk, or white varieties
Contains compounds that can improve mood
Belgium and Switzerland are famous for producing high-quality versions
This caffeinated beverage is made from roasted beans
Ethiopia is considered the birthplace of this drink
Can be served as espresso, cappuccino, or americano
The beans grow in tropical regions around the world
Many people rely on this to start their day
This Italian dish consists of a flatbread base
Traditionally topped with tomato sauce and mozzarella
Naples is considered the birthplace of the modern version
Popular toppings include pepperoni, mushrooms, and peppers
Often baked in a wood-fired oven for the best results
This Cantonese cuisine consists of small plates
Traditionally served with Chinese tea
Popular items include dumplings and buns
Often served from rolling carts in restaurants
The name means "touch the heart" in Chinese
This German beer festival takes place annually in Munich
Originally celebrated the marriage of Crown Prince Ludwig
Features traditional Bavarian music, food, and clothing
Visitors wear lederhosen and dirndls
Despite its name, it actually begins in September
This festive celebration occurs before Lent
Famous for elaborate costumes, parades, and dancing
Rio de Janeiro hosts one of the most famous versions
Venice is known for its elegant masked balls
New Orleans calls their version Mardi Gras
This Mexican holiday honors deceased family members
Takes place on November 1st and 2nd
Families create colorful altars called ofrendas
Sugar skulls and marigolds are traditional decorations
The name means "Day of the Dead" in English
This celebration marks the beginning of the lunar calendar
Also known as the Spring Festival
Features dragon and lion dances
Red envelopes with money are given as gifts
Each year is associated with one of twelve zodiac animals
This Hindu festival is known as the Festival of Colors
Celebrates the arrival of spring and victory of good over evil
People throw colored powder and water at each other
Traditionally associated with the love story of Krishna and Radha
Celebrated primarily in India and Nepal
This Hindu festival is known as the Festival of Lights
Celebrates the victory of light over darkness
People light oil lamps called diyas
Families exchange sweets and gifts
Fireworks displays are common during this celebration
This passionate art form originated in Andalusia, Spain
Combines singing, guitar playing, dancing, and handclaps
Dancers often wear colorful ruffled dresses
The guitar style is characterized by complex fingerpicking
UNESCO recognized it as a Masterpiece of Oral and Intangible Heritage
This traditional Japanese theater art form began in the early 17th century
Features elaborate makeup, costumes, and stylized movements
Originally performed by women, now performed only by men
Stories often involve historical events or moral conflicts
The name comes from a verb meaning "to lean" or "to be out of the ordinary"
This film industry is based in Mumbai, India
Known for colorful musicals with elaborate dance sequences
Produces more films annually than Hollywood
Movies often feature themes of family, love, and tradition
The name is a combination of Bombay and Hollywood
This streaming service started as a DVD-by-mail company
Now produces original content like "Stranger Things" and "The Crown"
Available in over 190 countries worldwide
Uses algorithms to recommend content to users
Headquarters are located in Los Gatos, California
This franchise features interconnected superhero movies
Started with "Iron Man" in 2008
Characters include Spider-Man, Thor, and Black Widow
"Avengers: Endgame" was one of its highest-grossing films
Owned by The Walt Disney Company
This social media app is known for short-form videos
Owned by the Chinese company ByteDance
Popular among younger users for dancing and comedy content
Videos are typically 15 seconds to 3 minutes long
Has faced scrutiny over data privacy concerns
This video-sharing platform was founded in 2005
Users can upload, watch, and share videos
Owned by Google since 2006
Content creators can monetize their channels
The first video uploaded was titled "Me at the zoo"
This music streaming service was founded in Sweden
Offers both free and premium subscription tiers
Users can create and share playlists
Provides personalized recommendations like "Discover Weekly"
Has over 400 million monthly active users worldwide
This photo and video-sharing app was launched in 2010
Owned by Meta (formerly Facebook)
Features include Stories, Reels, and IGTV
Popular among influencers and businesses for marketing
Uses hashtags to categorize and discover content
This mobile device combines phone and computer functions
Features a touchscreen interface
Can run various applications or "apps"
Includes features like camera, GPS, and internet access
The iPhone revolutionized this device category in 2007
This technology simulates human intelligence in machines
Applications include machine learning and natural language processing
Used in virtual assistants like Siri and Alexa
Can analyze large amounts of data to find patterns
Raises ethical questions about automation and employment
This digital currency was created by the mysterious Satoshi Nakamoto
Uses blockchain technology for secure transactions
Not controlled by any government or central authority
Can be "mined" using powerful computer hardware
Value is highly volatile and speculative
This technology delivers computing services over the internet
Allows users to access data and applications from anywhere
Services include storage, databases, and software
Major providers include Amazon AWS, Microsoft Azure, and Google Cloud
Reduces the need for local hardware and maintenance
This technology creates immersive, computer-generated environments
Users typically wear special headsets to experience it
Applications include gaming, education, and training
Can simulate presence in real or imagined worlds
Often abbreviated as VR
This vehicle uses electric motors instead of gasoline engines
Powered by rechargeable battery packs
Tesla is a well-known manufacturer of these vehicles
Produces zero direct emissions
Charging stations are becoming more common worldwide
These online platforms allow users to share content and interact
Examples include Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram
Has changed how people communicate and get news
Can be used for marketing and building communities
Raises concerns about privacy and misinformation
This refers to buying and selling goods online
Amazon is the largest platform for this activity
Allows businesses to reach customers worldwide
Includes online payments and digital transactions
Has grown significantly, especially during the COVID-19 pandemic
This field focuses on protecting digital systems from attacks
Includes measures like firewalls, encryption, and antivirus software
Professionals in this field are called cybersecurity analysts
Threats include malware, phishing, and data breaches
Becoming increasingly important as more activities move online
This subset of AI enables computers to learn from data
Algorithms improve automatically through experience
Used in recommendation systems and image recognition
Does not require explicit programming for every task
Popular frameworks include TensorFlow and PyTorch
This hormone regulates blood sugar levels
Produced by the pancreas in healthy individuals
People with diabetes may need injections of this
Its discovery won the Nobel Prize in Physiology
Type 1 diabetics cannot produce this naturally
This medical imaging technique uses electromagnetic radiation
Can see through soft tissue to reveal bones
Discovered by Wilhelm Röntgen in 1895
Common use is diagnosing broken bones
Radiation exposure is kept to safe levels
This common painkiller also reduces inflammation
Originally derived from willow bark
Can help prevent heart attacks and strokes
One of the most widely used medications in the world
Generic name is acetylsalicylic acid
This imaging technique uses magnetic fields and radio waves
Provides detailed images of soft tissues
Patients must remain very still during the procedure
The machine makes loud knocking sounds
Stands for Magnetic Resonance Imaging
This cancer treatment uses powerful drugs
Can cause side effects like hair loss and nausea
Often given in cycles over several months
May be combined with radiation or surgery
Works by targeting rapidly dividing cells
This medical technique prevents pain during surgery
Can be local, regional, or general
Revolutionized modern surgery
Administered by specialized doctors called anesthesiologists
Early forms included ether and chloroform
This emergency procedure helps restart the heart
Involves chest compressions and rescue breathing
Can be performed by trained bystanders
Should be started immediately during cardiac arrest
Stands for Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation
This measurement indicates the force of blood against artery walls
Recorded as two numbers, like 120 over 80
High levels increase risk of heart disease and stroke
Measured using a device called a sphygmomanometer
Can be affected by diet, exercise, and stress
This procedure replaces a failing organ with a healthy one
Requires careful matching between donor and recipient
Recipients must take immunosuppressive drugs for life
Common types include heart, liver, and kidney
First successful one was performed in 1954
This occurs when bacteria evolve to survive antibiotic treatment
Caused by overuse and misuse of antibiotics
Creates "superbugs" that are hard to treat
A major global health concern
Can be prevented by completing full antibiotic courses
This computing method uses quantum mechanical phenomena
Uses quantum bits or "qubits" instead of regular bits
Could solve certain problems exponentially faster
Still largely experimental and theoretical
Companies like IBM and Google are developing these systems
This type of energy comes from naturally replenishing sources
Includes solar, wind, and hydroelectric power
Considered more environmentally friendly than fossil fuels
Costs have decreased significantly in recent years
Key to addressing climate change
This treatment involves inserting genetic material into cells
Aims to treat or prevent disease at the genetic level
Still largely experimental but showing promise
Could potentially cure inherited disorders
Raises ethical questions about genetic modification
This technology creates tamper-resistant digital records
Uses cryptographic hashing to link blocks of data
The foundation technology behind cryptocurrencies
Can provide transparency and security for transactions
Applications extend beyond digital currency
This gene-editing technology can precisely modify DNA
Stands for Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats
Originally discovered as part of bacterial immune systems
Could potentially cure genetic diseases
Raises ethical concerns about genetic modification
